title: How is listening to classical music helpful to improve your memory? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very interesting question, I am trying to explain according to my understanding : Listing classical music will give you a calm effect in your mind.With a calm state of mind you can concentrate on anything.With concentration you can learn anything very well and fast too……….because that learning will be very effective for both conscious and subconscious mind, once you can start to train your subconscious mind, its likely that your memory will be improved.

Not per se, if you’re talking about studying. If you like the music, if it calms you down, and it does not draw your attention, it can help you concentrate. The genre doesn’t matter: it’s whatever works for you. (Personally, I prefer listening to brown noise when I have to concentrate, because music draws my attention.) As for memory, it has been shown that if we encode memories while being in one state (e.g. underwater), it’s easier to recall those memories when in that same state (e.g. underwater). State-dependent memory - Wikipedia This suggests that if you study while listening to classical music, you should do a bit better on the test if you write it while listening to classical music. However, sadly, such an activity would likely not be permitted in the exam room. No headphones or devices, ya know. This is why it’s best to study in a state as similar to the exam as possible: quiet. But … if you’re talking about dementia or Alzheimer’s, … familiar music may facilitate attention, reward and motivation, which in turn makes it more possible to manage emotional distress in Alzheimer’s. Current Research - Music and Memory Music and Memory: 5 Awesome New Psychology Studies - PsyBlog … but again, it seems the genre doesn’t matter.
